author: zorozor1
content:
Would any of the EL teams find value in performance tests that test the execution client with a consensus client that attempts to produce blocks as fast as possible with a single sequencer? i.e. it does loops of GetPaylodV2, NewPayloadV2 and FCUV2. 
My thinking is that it would be a good way to test the upper bounds of gas per second an execution client can process, which is valuable for L2s/sidechains picking up ELs as their starting point

author: potuz
content: I imagine for such a scenario as you want to do, with no forks and a centralized sequencer, why would you want to even have a separate CL client and communicate via REST to the EL? I'd just integrate the sequencer to the EL and bypass these calls

author: zorozor1
content: Fair point. I'm doing it in separate CL since that's my path of inertia as I'm building out my own CL with a different consensus algo. It would also make it easier since I don't have to modify all the ELs and can just rely on Engine API

author: potuz
content: It's true that it's simpler to get client diversity that way, but I suspect that you're likely to bottleneck on REST more than in gas per minute.

author: zorozor1
content: Interesting, I'd be surprised if REST is the bottleneck if both EL and CL are on same machine, but possibly. My guess is Payload creation would be the bottleneck

author: potuz
content: I guess it would also depend on slot time

author: ryanleeschneider
content:
So geth 1.13.3 added a new log warning about `Announced transaction size mismatch` (see: https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/pull/28261).  However this seems to be trigger a _lot_ (this host has logged that message 120458 times in the last 2h) so it seems like something we should track down the cause of.

To assist with that I just collected the `peer` field from the last 2h of `Announced transaction size mismatch` logs on one of my 1.13.3 nodes and then used `admin_peers` to check my other nodes if they were connected to this one, and here's the client ids I was able to acquire using that technique:

```
   5     name: "Nethermind/v1.20.1+9f39c0c7/linux-x64/dotnet7.0.9",
   2     name: "erigon/v2.48.1-stable-674b77f0/linux-amd64/go1.20.6",
   2     name: "Nethermind/v1.20.4+d06ec791/linux-x64/dotnet7.0.11",
   1     name: "erigon/v2.50.1/linux-amd64/go1.20.7",
   1     name: "erigon/v2.43.0/linux-amd64/go1.20.2",
   1     name: "erigon/v2.43.0/linux-amd64/go1.20",
   1     name: "erigon/v2.43.0-stable-1106475e/linux-amd64/go1.20.4",
   1     name: "besu/v23.7.2/linux-x86_64/openjdk-java-17",
   1     name: "Nethermind/v1.20.3+e8c161a5/linux-x64/dotnet7.0.10",
   1     name: "Nethermind/v1.19.3+e8ac1da4/linux-x64/dotnet7.0.8",
```

I find it surprising that three different codebases (Nethermind, besu, erigon) would all have the same issue, anyone have more insight into what might be going on here?
